awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Wearable Research for In-Service STEM Teachers (WRIST)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award renews an exemplary Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site on wearable computing research at the University of Nebraska at Omaha (UNO). The RET site nurtures a long-term partnership between UNO and Omaha Public Schools to advance pre-college science and engineering education by providing cutting-edge research experiences to cohorts of high school teachers in the areas of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). The research projects will focus on emerging wearable technologies and provide hands-on experiments and daily interactions with faculty mentors who are actively involved in leading-edge research on wearable computing. The participating teachers will translate their research experiences and knowledge into classroom practice by developing instructional modules and course materials that they will introduce in their classrooms and share with other teachers in their school district. These activities all contribute to the formation of a community of practice in partnership with UNO faculty and industry mentors that has the potential to significantly enhance and improve STEM education in the Omaha Public School District.

The participating teachers will attend a 6-week summer institute to participate in cutting-edge research projects with mentoring from computer science faculty who lead vibrant wearable computing research programs. This RET Site project will provide a platform for the participating teachers to develop practical problem-based instructional materials and laboratory modules that they will share with other teachers in their school district during an academic year workshop. The teacher-created modules and lessons will be disseminated nationally through TeachEngineering.org, a nationally recognized repository for searchable, standards-based engineering curricula.   The RET Site project will boost the quality of instruction in the Omaha Public Schools and strengthen the curricula. The excitement of learning about innovative computing technologies can inspire the students to pursue further computing education and related careers.  The WRIST program will strengthen ongoing partnerships between the University of Nebraska and Omaha Public Schools and synergize community computer science education initiatives that lay the foundation for quality computing education in the schools and provide for the future computing workforce needs of the community.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the RET Site program was to help build long-term collaborative partnerships between K-12 STEM teachers, community college faculty, and the university research community by involving the teachers and community college faculty in engineering and computer science research, and helping them translate their research experiences and new knowledge into classroom activities.  


Outcomes Related to Intellectual Merit

To achieve the goal of the RET WRIST site program, middle school and high school teachers were recruited from urban, suburban and rural school districts. The mentors and mentees teamed to perform successfully the challenging research projects and developed corresponding lesson plans, course modules, and instructional materials that translate the research results into teaching during the summer session.  The research projects conducted in the summer cover and represent the diverse areas of interests and expertise the CS faculty engage and possess, while all focusing on the theme of wearable computing. 

The lessons were integrated into a diverse range of classrooms: Science (12), Technology (10), Math (5), Engineering (3), Language Arts (2), Music (2), Physical Education (2). This shows that the approach to create personalized implementation portfolios can successfully generate CS lessons in each of these diverse disciplines, in a variety of school contexts.

Participating Teachers showed a statistically significant increase in several categories of the Teacher Perspectives Questionnaire. The TPQ measured the participants' perceptions about their CS knowledge, skills, and their ability to implement the Problem-Based Learning (PBL) methodology. The participant survey data (pre- and post-WRIST) shows that the participants view themselves as having increased their knowledge of Computer Science, Computer Science Research, Mobile Applications, Programming, STEM Education, and Problem Based Learning through the WRIST program. Furthermore, the RET teachers moved toward a more expert attitude about CS, especially in terms of approaching problem solving, connecting CS to the real world, and increased personal interest,.

Five papers were published at peer-reviewed national/international conferences, using a browser-based programming language to Engage Students (ICER2018 and SIGCSE 2019), introducing the Machine Learning Exercises for High School Students (SIGCSE 2019, CSTA 2020), and detecting posture when playing a musical instrument using wearable sensors (NAfME 2021).


Outcomes Related to Broader Impacts

For the past five years, 43 teachers were recruited for this RET site program. This included 18 male and 25 female teachers. The RET participants were actively involved in multiple research projects and over 40 lessons were developed and delivered in the past five years.

The WRIST site program hosted three WRIST Spring Workshop between 2018 and 2020. These follow-up workshops were populated primarily by local STEM teachers for sharing, exchanging, and dissemination the summer research and course materials.  105 teachers attended the Spring workshops between 2018 and 2020. Participating teachers came from 18 schools spanning five counties in eastern Nebraska surrounding the city of Omaha, an area with about 51% of Nebraska’s population, and one county in western Iowa surrounding the city of Council Bluffs. A total of 83.3% (15) of the schools were public, including six schools in the Omaha Public School (OPS) district.

The project led to the establishment of a new Master of Science degree program in Computer Science Education (MS-CSE), jointly offered by the CS and Teacher EDucation (TED) departments at UNO. The visibility of the WRIST program was also instrumental in the establishment of the Graduate Certificate in CS Education, and the IT/Computer Science Supplemental Endorsement. Eight RET teachers have been admitted into this program pathway to date. These new graduate education pathways will allow the RET teachers as well as local CS teachers to continue to increase their learning trajectory, and to increasingly become CS Education leaders in their districts, the city, state and nation.

It also is important to note that the project continues to represent a very synergistic and steady “ramp up” of computer science education by UNO and the area schools. In particular, this project nurtured the creation of a local ACM CSTA (Computer Science Teachers Association) chapter - the Metropolitan Omaha CSTA Chapter. The UNO RET Site faculty team and the participating teachers served as founding members and chapter officers.

In addition, the WRIST project has also established a close working relationship within the Metropolitan Omaha Area Schools (MOEC) districts. UNO is increasingly becoming known in MOEC for our evolving city and statewide leadership in K-12 computer science. Momentum is building, and we are increasingly getting calls from the area teachers and districts inquiring about our CS education related efforts for potential participation.
